citeinfo.title: Coded Water Conflict and Crisis Events in the Colorado River Basin, Derived from LexisNexis search 2005-2021

descript.abstract: The data in this data release are from an effort focused on understanding social vulnerability to water insecurity, resiliency demonstrated by institutions, and conflict or crisis around water resource management. This data release focuses on the conflict in crisis aspects of work. To characterize crisis a dual-prong, qualitative triangulation was used to identify and provide context for water conflict and other water-related events in the Colorado River Basin. The first prong was observation by research team members of nine public, recorded meetings of water control boards and official organizations in the Colorado River Basin. Discourse analysis was then used to identify major themes in these meetings, and integrated into data from the second prong of this project. The second prong was a search, cataloguing, and contextualization of articles from newspapers describing water-related events in geographic areas in the Basin based on methods established by Dr. Nathan Eidem. USGS applied this methodology to a new time period of data to extend the work. This kind of approach has value for examining Crisis on a continual basis toward identification of hotspots from conflict, identifying primary stakeholders, and who experiences Crises. This resulting dataset catalogues events in the Colorado River Basin (particularly the Upper Colorado River Basin in most cases) from 2005 - 2021. This table extends the the Upper Colorado Events Database which catalogues simiar events from 1970 - 2005. Events are defined as any interaction between parties that is action-defined, recorded, and made available to the public. The criteria for inclusion we used for the LexisNexis search is as follows: each event must be driven by some aspect or dimension of freshwater resources and occur within the study area. Each event is described comprehensively and coded with themes that correspond to themes from the first prong to provide proof of each themes contribution to conflict in the Basin (see Colorado River Basin Water Conflict Table). Given resource constraints some events were not fully coded but are included in the Uncoded Events table as a resource to other researchers in the future.
descript.purpose: The data were collected to catalogue and understand water-related conflicts in the Colorado River Basin. This benefits the growing human dimension research that USGS Water Mission Area is conducting and may be a source of background information to the water availability assessment reports which USGS is producing as a series of reports over the next few years.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted. Quality of data was ensured through procedural consistency amongst team members.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical consistency tests were conducted.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Data represents occurrences only with the Colorado River Basin.

citeinfo.origin: Amy Bilyeau, Librarian, Department of Interior, amy_bilyeau@ios.doi.gov; and George D. Franchois, Library Director, george_franchois@ios.doi.gov
citeinfo.title: Newspaper articles pulled from LexisNexis, 631 results

Eidem, N. 2008. The Western Water Institutional Solutions-Western Water Information Network Collaboration: An Analysis of the Social, Economic, and Biophysical Environments Supportive of and the Historic Trends in Conflict and Cooperation in the Bureau of Reclamation's Upper Colorado Region 1970-2005. Reclamation: Managing Water in the West.

srcinfo.srccontr: Provided categories applied to events during textual analysis

citeinfo.title: Eidem, N. 2012. Enhancing Social-Ecological Resilience in the Colorado River Basin.

srcinfo.srccontr: Provided intensity scale and references to researched applied to events during textual analysis

citeinfo.title: Eidem, N. 2012. Enhancing Social-Ecological Resilience in the Colorado River Basin.

srcinfo.srccontr: The UC Events Database (https://transboundarywaters.science.oregonstate.edu/sites/transboundarywaters.science.oregonstate.edu/files/Database/ResearchProjects/Colorado/Final_WWIS_UC_Event_Database.xls) provided stakeholder categories to researchers and were applied to events during textual analysis

procstep.procdesc: Articles for this work were pulled from LexisNexis using the following search criteria: Rio Grande River and Pecos River and Colorado River and Gunnison River and San Juan River and Sevier River and Green River and Animas River and La Plata River and Great Salt Lake OR water OR river! OR dam OR stream OR tributary OR irrigation OR channel OR reservoir AND quality OR flood! OR drought! OR rights AND treaty or agree or negotiate or partner or settle or cooperate or collaborate or dispute or conflict or disagree or war or protest. After collecting the resulting 631 articles, members of this research team read 269 articles, and utilizing corresponding themes, provided context and further coded articles based on their content.

enttyp.enttypl: Colorado River Basin Water Conflict Table.csv
enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing contextualization of articles.

attr.attrdef: Name of the newspaper where the article was published
The title of the article

Whether or not this same article appears again in this dataset. The researchers left these included because they are syndications of the same content in several different newspapers and their appearance more than once captures significance of stories appearing in several locations throughout the geographic area.
Date the newspaper article was published

attrdomv.udom: Specific date or month the article was published

attr.attrdef: Year the newspaper article was published
Date of the event described in the newspaper article

edom.edomvd: The event date was not coded or could not be identified during coding.

attrdomv.udom: Date of the event described in the newspaper article as captured by the researcher during coding. May be a range of dates if pertinent.

attr.attrdef: Day of the event described in the newspaper article. Coded from the Event Date contents.

edom.edomvd: Day was not coded.

attr.attrdef: Month of the event described in the newspaper article. Coded from the Event Date contents.

edom.edomvd: Month was not coded.

attr.attrdef: Year of the event described in the newspaper article. Coded from the Event Date contents.

edom.edomvd: Year was not coded.

attr.attrdef: Binary response to "Is a conflict present?" Conflict is defined here as an incompatibility of goals and various attempts of any present parties to control each other's choices. When the researchers reviewed the articles, they were looking for evidence of this behavior in the event explained.

edom.edomvd: The event was not coded for conflict
Yes, conflict evidence was observed.
No, conflict evidence was not observed.

attr.attrdef: Binary response to "is a crisis present?" Crisis here is defined as a time of intense difficulty or danger. When the researchers reviewed the articles, they were looking for evidence of this behavior in the event explained.

edom.edomvd: The event was not coded for crisis
Yes, crisis in event was observed
No, crisis in event was not observed

attr.attrdef: Smaller basins and watersheds where the event took place or was most directly felt. When the researchers reviewed the articles, they were looking for specific geographic locations for the events mentioned that can be intersected with a HUC6 watershed/basin. The researchers used an interactive map interface with several overlapping geospatial layers (HUC6 data layer, major cities layer, US Census urban areas layer) to locate and code the basin.

edom.edomvd: Empty cell indicates a basin was not coded for this event. NA indicates a basin is not referenced in the event.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey Watershed Boundary Dataset

attrdomv.udom: Names of the HUC6 basin within the Upper Colorado River Basin

attr.attrdef: HUC6 watershed/basins where the event took place or impacted. Coded from Basin field.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey Watershed Boundary Dataset

attrdomv.udom: Unique ID number for each HUC6 basin mentioned in the article.

attr.attrdef: HUC2 watershed/basins where the event took place or impacted. Coded from Basin field.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey Watershed Boundary Dataset

attrdomv.udom: Unique ID number for each HUC2 basin mentioned in the article.

attr.attrdef: Where the event actually occurred, but also where the event's direct implications are felt most directly. When the researchers reviewed the articles, they were looking for mentions of specific places impacted by the events.

edom.edomvd: Empty cell indicates a place was not coded for this event. NA indicates a place is not referenced in the event text.

attrdomv.udom: Names of places described in the article

attr.attrdef: County names coded from Place names.

edom.edomvd: Empty cell indicates a county was not coded for this event or that the article was not coded.

attr.attrdef: County FIPS Code coded from Place names.

edom.edomvd: Empty cell indicates a county was not coded for this event or that the article was not coded.

attr.attrdef: State Name coded from Place field.

edom.edomvd: Empty cell indicates a state was not coded for this event or that the article was not coded.

attr.attrdef: State FIPS Code coded from Place field.

edom.edomvd: Empty cell indicates a state was not coded for this event or that the article was not coded.

attr.attrdef: Does this event impact an urban or rural space? The researchers consulted an interactive map containing several geospatial layers, including an urban area geospatial layer from the United States Census (published 2021) to determine if the Place(s) mentioned in the article are urban or rural or perhaps both if a larger area that includes both kinds of landscapes is referenced.

edom.edomvd: An empty cell indicates that the event was not coded or categorized. NA indicates that it does not apply to this event.
Event pertains to both urban and rural areas
Event pertains to a rural area
Event pertains to an urban area

attr.attrdef: The type of event/issue, as defined by the US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project. Definitions of the issue types are based on US Western Water Institutional analysis, Eidem 2008.

edom.edomvd: Water conservation measures not fully implemented. Includes agriculture, municipal, industrial uses and conveyance methods, and water usage limitations.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Issue of water quantity and water supply. Past, current, or future drought implications on water supply.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Dam/hydropower facilities block fish passage or inhibit fish survival (but not in relation to water quality). Related actions include fish ladders, dam removal, and bypasses which may affect water supply.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Reservoir levels decreased for future storage. Implies loss of water for future use and bypassed electrical generation.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Withdrawing too much ground water too quickly thereby not allowing recharge of aquifer or other substantial water table lowering. Ground water use depletes surface water flows, or leads to land subsidence. Creation of new ground water supply source.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Water conveyance, storage, or treatment non-existent, in disrepair, inadequate or not predicted to meet future needs due to agricultural or municipal/population growth. Creating, expanding, and repairing these systems. New surface water source development and public works project funding. Includes conjunctive storage of excess surface water in ground water cavities. Also include issues over storm water and flood protection.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: River flows/lake levels are too low to support threatened or endangered species due to high consumptive uses. Governmental institutions requiring higher instream flows, and other stakeholder groups obtaining/transferring water rights to instream uses. Includes water to comply with the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Disputes over allocation of water among international, federal, state, local institutions, and other stakeholder groups and private citizens; including between Upper and Lower Colorado basins and other upstream/downstream entities. Includes allocations of diversions from federal projects (i.e. BOR reservoirs), allocation disputes from existing out of-basin transfers and citizen or stakeholder voting. Also includes jurisdictional and management issues.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Water right in dispute or in litigation and basin adjudication. Also includes halts on development without a required water right and other issues related to property rights. Includes Native American claims to water and reactions to their claims. Includes lease and sale of water rights for consumptive use.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Either local water will be transferred out of basin or an area basin relies on out of-basin water-- includes both givers and receivers of water. A stakeholder searching to create an out of-basin water supply or alter the amount of current out-of-basin supply. Involved stakeholders may refuse or agree to alter water quantity. (The dispute over the allocation of that water would be included in Intergovernmental. If the amount increases and there is a need or desire to increase storage it would be included in Infrastructure)
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

edom.edomvd: Surface or ground water does not meet local, state or federal standards for municipal use or endangered species regulations or alteration of those standards. May be due to numerous activities including but not limited to: violation of NPDES permit, discharge of toxic or hazardous waste or salt water intrusion. Includes stakeholder concern over potential degradation of water quality due to any activity. Includes fluoride additions to municipal water supply.
edom.edomvds: US Western Water Institutional Solutions Project

attr.attrdef: A summary of the event captured by the researchers reviewing the article, as described in the article.

edom.edomvd: The event was not coded by researchers.

attr.attrdef: The stake-holders mentioned in the article who were involved. These generalized stake-holder categories were applied to each article's event to classify stake-holders involved. Stake-holder categories came from a unique list of options available from the Eidem 2012, which were summarized from the published Excel file that corresponded with the Eidem 2012 dissertation, the Western Water Institutional Solutions Upper Colorado Conflict Event database.
attr.attrdefs: Eidem 2012 and WWIS UC Conflict Event database

edom.edomvd: The article was not coded for stake-holders.

attrdomv.udom: The stake-holders mentioned in the article

attr.attrdef: A measure of the intensity of the event. The more negative or positive a value, the more negative or positive the event. Intensity values range from intense conflict (-5) to intense cooperation (5). Researchers used the scale available and compared the event descriptions in the article to the scale options and selected the most appropriate value to reflect the level of intensity in the conflict/crises.

edom.edomvd: The event was not coded or the event was not coded for event intensity

Hostility: Included actions: Protests, personal threats, vandalism, private citizen shooting, and arrests. Police forces called out in small numbers (arrests) and violent instances involving private citizens causing injury, destruction, or death. Construction of water project against major stakeholders wishes on small (local) scale. Theme: Small scale acts of police force, violence, and threats

Litigation: Included actions: filing and appeals, appeal of administrative actions or permit denials. Does NOT include judicial rulings. Dissolution of agency or management groups. Formal filing of protest of agreements, creation of opposition groups (needs two events: one conflictive and one cooperative). Theme: Judicial intervention or Management group dissolution.

Dispute: Included actions: Halting negotiations, refusal to be involved or to include other stakeholders in negotiations or settlements. Regulatory violations- illegal water withdrawals. Regulatory enforcement actions, fines. Permit application or proposal denials from authorities. Expressed intent to litigate, impose economic sanctions and other violent threat. Theme: Cooperative group meltdown or authoritative regulatory action.

Disagreement: Included actions: Official refusal of proposed settlements or negotiations, threat to halt negotiations. Negotiations may fail, but without a complete withdrawal from them. Withdrawal of third party support- governmental, monetary or figuratively, and petitions, bill blocking. Other request denials. Theme: Roadblocks or temporary failure of settlement or project progress.

Difference: Included actions: General statements of disapproval or opposition including Op-Ed, fact contention, report or findings review, preliminary refusal of proposals or settlements and warnings. Delay in negotiations or vote, and stakeholder exclusion from input. Theme: Voicing opinions of opposition, but not in enough force to achieve project blockage.

Neutral or Insignificant: Included actions: Indifferent statements, no comment statements. Court ruling, court or congressional testimony, congressional hearing, and fact clarification. Theme: Events have no major effect on party interactions. Does not decrease nor increase conflictive intensity of interaction.

Similarity: Included actions: General statements of approval or agreement including Op-Ed, fact agreement, preliminary approval of proposals, actions or bills. Inclusion of stakeholder input or review, following voluntary guidelines, court-mandated negotiations. Announcements including project or institution goals or policies and project proposals, research, and calls for more research. Theme: Voicing opinions of approval, but not with enough force to make major forward moves toward resolution.

Agreement: Included actions: Acceptance of a preliminary proposal or settlement, calls for negotiation or mediation sessions. Third party support such as governmental or monetary assistance. Apologizing for past actions, meetings that are not for settlement or negotiations, dropping project opposition. Information release upon request, lawyer-recommended settlement acceptance. Theme: Progress in stakeholder agreements and minor project support.

Assent: Included actions: Agreeing to participate in and stakeholder inclusion in settlements and negotiations, preliminary settlement and negotiation agreement, resuming negotiations. Agreement to fix regulatory violations, basic water right and other permit approvals by an authoritative body. Creating forums. Preliminary settlement and negotiation agreement (still need official approval). Theme: Preliminary agreement to settlement and regulatory compliance.

Cooperative Management: Included actions: Out of court or negotiation agreement reached, bill passage; transfer of management-- including sales and leases. Formation of management groups across political lines, formation of advocacy groups, cooperative projects for watershed management, irrigation. Theme: Legally binding cooperation actions like regulation approval and lawsuit settlements

Formal Agreement: Included actions: Compacts and official agreements signed or ratified between states, municipalities or nations. Formal signing of document, merger of private sector or unification of small scale (local) governmental body. small scale (local)(governmental body). Theme: Major Alliance: Compacts and management or authorities group unification.

attr.attrdef: Additional notes from the research team. These comments explain values, codes, and themes used for each event.

edom.edomvd: No specific comments on this article or the article was not coded.

attrdomv.udom: Additional notes from the research team. These comments explain values, codes, and themes used for each event.

attr.attrdef: Themes were created during an early phase of the project based on conducted observations of public water board meetings. Here they are applied as they were also observed in the newspaper articles about conflict and crises.

edom.edomvd: No related themes were applied or the article was not coded.
Observed that no tribal representation was present in discussion of issues that impacted tribal issues.
Observed continuation with discussions and negotiations even while acknowledging that important impacted groups are not at the table.
Not applicable/No related theme noted
Observed beneficial collaboration between State and water control boards
Observed the preference of scientific knowledge used to make decisions and discuss issues and events.
Observed exclusionary procedural governance wherein those who are unfamiliar with the procedures used would be unable to participate in the discussions and be involved.
Observed that other types of knowledge not represented, as a corrolary to scientific knowledges preferred in discussions and decision-making.
Observed rigid procedural governance/behavior that does not leave space for those unfamiliar with established and accepted processes to engage.

Observed shallow engagement strategies (such as a reference to a single email or letter sent to invite external voices) mentioned when attempting to bring outsiders into existing rigid procedural governance processes.
Observed lack of shared values for tribal land and resources
Observed personal relationships or existing relationships as being necessary to engage with decisionmakers
Observed admitted lack of relationships between State officials and tribal groups mentioned
Observed lack of shared values with tribal values
Observed a lack of involvement
Observed processes used that did not allow everyone to participate
Observed processes which did not include public comment

attr.attrdef: Number of times "water quality" was mentioned in the article, as discovered by an R (statistical programming language) command str_detect(). This is one of the issue types described in Eidem 2008.

Number of times "ground water depletion" was mentioned in the article, as discovered by an R (statistical programming language) command str_detect(). This is one of the issue types described in Eidem 2008.
Number of times "depletion" was mentioned in the article, as discovered by an R (statistical programming language) command str_detect(). This is one of the issue types described in Eidem 2008.
Number of times "infrastructure" was mentioned in the article, as discovered by an R (statistical programming language) command str_detect(). This is one of the issue types described in Eidem 2008.
Number of times "fish passage" was mentioned in the article, as discovered by an R (statistical programming language) command str_detect(). This is one of the issue types described in Eidem 2008.

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes, nor on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. The use of firm, trade, or brand names in this report is for identification purposes only and does not constitute endorsement by the U.S. Geological Survey.
